When an appropriate subtype is not available in the Audiovisual Core controlled vocabulary, a term IRI that is not in a TDWG namespace MAY be used. Conforming applications MAY choose to ignore controlled values not issued by Audiovisual Core. See ac:subtypeLiteral for usage with strings.
fields.rdfs:comment: A class, represented by an IRI, that provides for more specialization of the media item type than dcterms:type.

fields.name: collectionCode
fields.title: Collection Code
fields.description: A name, acronym, coden, or initialism identifying a collection.
fields.rdfs:comment: The name, acronym, coden, or initialism identifying the collection or data set from which the record was derived.

fields.name: collectionID
fields.title: Collection ID
fields.description: An identifier for a collection.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the collection or dataset from which the record was derived.

fields.name: CreateDate
fields.title: Original Date and Time
fields.description: The date and time a resource was created. For a digital file, this need not match a file-system creation time. For a freshly created resource, it should be close to that time, modulo the time taken to write the file. Later file transfer, copying, and so on, can make the file-system time arbitrarily different.
fields.comments: The date of the creation of the original resource from which the digital media was derived or created. The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). When applied to a media resource with temporal extent such as audio or video, this property indicates the startTime of the recording. What constitutes "original" is determined by the metadata author. Example: Digitization of a photographic slide of a map would normally give the date at which the map was created; however a photographic work of art including the same map as its content may give the date of the original photographic exposure. Imprecise or unknown dates can be represented as ISO dates or ranges. Compare also Date and Time Digitized in the Resource Creation Vocabulary. See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.
fields.rdfs:comment: The date and time the resource was created. For a digital file, this need not match a file-system creation time. For a freshly created resource, it should be close to that time, modulo the time taken to write the file. Later file transfer, copying, and so on, can make the file-system time arbitrarily different.

fields.name: timeOfDay
fields.title: Time Of Day
fields.description: Free text information beyond exact clock times.
fields.rdfs:comment: Free text information beyond exact clock times.

fields.name: digitizationDate
fields.title: Digitization Date
fields.description: A date on which the first digital version of a resource was created, if different from xmp:CreateDate.
fields.comments: The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). Use the international (ISO/xml) format yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm (e. g. "2007-12-31" or "2007-12-31T14:59"). Where available, timezone information SHOULD be added. This is often not the media creation or modification date. For example, if photographic prints have been scanned, the date of that scanning is what this term carries, but Original Date and Time is that depicted in the print. In the case of digital images containing EXIF, whereas the EXIF capture date does not contain time zone information, but EXIF GPSDateStamp and GPSTimeStamp may be relevant as these include time-zone information. See also Metadata Working Group Guidelines for Handling Image Metadata, Version 2.0 (November 2010), https://web.archive.org/web/20180919181934/http://www.metadataworkinggroup.org/pdf/mwg_guidance.pdf, which has best practice advice on handling time-zone-less EXIF date/time data. See also the Wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.
fields.rdfs:comment: Date the first digital version was created, if different from Original Date and Time found in the Temporal Coverage Vocabulary.

fields.name: captureDevice
fields.title: Capture Device
fields.description: Free form text describing the device or devices used to create the resource.
fields.comments: It is best practice to record the device; this may include a combination such as camera plus lens, or camera plus microscope. Examples: "Canon Supershot 2000", "Makroscan Scanner 2000", "Zeiss Axioscope with Camera IIIu", "SEM (Scanning Electron Microscope)".
fields.rdfs:comment: Free form text describing the device or devices used to create the resource.

fields.name: frameRate
fields.title: Frame Rate
fields.description: The decimal fraction representing the frequency (rate) at which consecutive images (frames) were captured in real time for a dcmi:MovingImage, expressed as the number of frames per second.
fields.comments: This term represents the rate at which consecutive images were captured in real time, not the rate at which the media is encoded to play back the recording. For example, in a recording where 60 consecutive images (frames) are captured for each second of the real-time recording, this would be 60. In a time-lapse recording where one image (frame) is recorded every 5 seconds of recording, this would be 0.2.
fields.rdfs:comment: The decimal fraction representing the frequency (rate) at which consecutive images (frames) were captured in real time for a moving image, expressed as the number of frames per second.

fields.name: resourceCreationTechnique
fields.title: Resource Creation Technique
fields.description: Information about technical aspects of the creation and digitization process of the resource. This includes modification steps ("retouching") after the initial resource capture.
fields.comments: Annotating whether and how a resource has been modified or edited significantly in ways that are not immediately obvious to, or expected by, consumers is of special significance. Examples for images are: Removing a distracting twig from a picture, moving an object to a different surrounding, changing the color in parts of the image, or blurring the background of an image. Modifications that are standard practice and expected or obvious are not necessary to document; examples of such practices include changing resolution, cropping, minor sharpening or overall color correction, and clearly perceptible modifications (e.g., addition of arrows or labels, or the placement of multiple pictures into a table.) If it is only known that significant modifications were made, but no details are known, a general statement like "Media may have been manipulated to improve appearance" may be appropriate. See also Subject Preparation Technique. Encoding method or settings, numbers of channels, lighting, frames per second, data rate, interlaced or progressive, multiflash lighting, remote control, automatic interval exposure.
fields.rdfs:comment: Information about technical aspects of the creation and digitization process of the resource. This includes modification steps ("retouching") after the initial resource capture.

fields.name: modified
fields.title: Modified
fields.description: Date on which the resource was changed.
fields.comments: Date that the media resource was altered. The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). dcterms:modified permits all modification dates to be recorded, or if only one is recorded, it is assumed to be the latest. See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.
fields.rdfs:comment: Date on which the resource was changed.

fields.name: language
fields.title: Language
fields.description: A language of the resource.
fields.comments: URI from the ISO639-2 list of URIs for ISO 3-letter language codes, http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-2. An image may contain language such as superimposed labels. If an image is of a natural scene or organism, without any language included, the resource is language-neutral with URI http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-2/zxx corresponding to ISO ISO639-2 code "zxx". Resources with present but unknown language are to be coded as undetermined, with URI http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-2/und corresponding to ISO639-2 code "und". Regional dialects or other special cases should conform to the ISO639-5 Alpha-3 Code for Language Families and Groups, http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-5.html, where possible or the IETF Best Practices for Tags Identifying Languages, https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5646, where not. See also the entry for dc:language in the Audiovisual Core term list document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: A language of the resource.

fields.name: languageIRI
fields.title: Language IRI
fields.description: A language of the resource.
fields.rdfs:comment: A language of the resource.

fields.name: MetadataDate
fields.title: Metadata Date
fields.description: The date and time that any metadata for this resource was last changed. It should be the same as or more recent than dcterms:modified.
fields.comments: Point in time recording when the last modification to metadata (not necessarily the media object itself) occurred. The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). This is not dcterms:modified, which refers to the resource itself rather than its metadata. See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.
fields.rdfs:comment: The date and time that any metadata for this resource was last changed. It should be the same as or more recent than xmp:ModifyDate.

fields.name: metadataLanguageLiteral
fields.title: Metadata Language Literal
fields.description: Language of description and other metadata (but not necessarily of the image itself) represented as an ISO639-2 three letter language code.
fields.comments: ISO639-1 two-letter codes are permitted but deprecated. At least one of ac:metadataLanguage and ac:metadataLanguageLiteral MUST be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both might make the metadata more widely useful. They MUST specify the same language. In case of ambiguity, ac:metadataLanguage prevails. This is NOT dc:language, which is about the resource, not the metadata. Metadata Language is deliberately single-valued, imposing on unstructured serializations a requirement that multi-lingual metadata be represented as separate, complete, metadata records. Audiovisual Core requires that each record also contains the language-neutral terms. In the absence of this requirement, metadata consumers would need to know which terms are language-neutral and merge these terms from all provided metadataLanguages into a single record. Metadata consumers may re-combine the information based on the dcterms:identifier that identifies the multimedia resource. Nothing in this document would, however, prevent an implementer, e. g. of an XML-Schema representation, from providing a fully hierarchical schema in which language neutral terms occur only a single time, and only the language-specific terms are repeated in a way that unambigously relates them to a metadata language. In RDF it may be a simple repetition of plain literals associated with a language (e.g., xml:lang attribute in RDF/XML). The language attribute would then be required in Audiovisual Core and would replace ac:metadataLanguage.
fields.rdfs:comment: Language of description and other metadata (but not necessarily of the image itself) represented as an ISO639-2 three letter language code.

fields.name: metadataLanguageIRI
fields.title: Metadata Language IRI
fields.description: The URI of the language of description and other metadata (but not necessarily of the image itself).
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the ISO639-2 list of URIs for ISO 3-letter language codes, http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-2. At least one of ac:metadataLanguage and ac:metadataLanguageLiteral should be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both might make the metadata more widely useful. They must specify the same language. In case of ambiguity, ac:metadataLanguage prevails. This is NOT dcterms:language, which is about the resource, not the metadata. Metadata Language is deliberately single-valued, imposing on unstructured serializations a requirement that multi-lingual metadata be represented as separate, complete, metadata records. Audiovisual Core requires that each record also contains the language-neutral terms. In the absence of this requirement, metadata consumers would need to know which terms are language-neutral and merge these terms from all provided metadataLanguages into a single record. Metadata consumers may re-combine the information based on the dcterms:identifier that identifies the multimedia resource. Nothing in this document would, however, prevent an implementer, e. g. of an XML-Schema representation, from providing a fully hierarchical schema in which language neutral terms occur only a single time, and only the language-specific terms are repeated in a way that unambigously relates them to a metadata language. In RDF it may be a simple repetition of plain literals associated with a language (e.g., xml:lang attribute in RDF/XML). The language attribute would then be required in Audiovisual Core and would replace ac:metadataLanguage.
fields.rdfs:comment: The URI of the language of description and other metadata (but not necessarily of the image itself) , from the ISO639-2 list of URIs for ISO 3-letter language codes, http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-2.

fields.name: providerManagedID
fields.title: Provider-managed ID
fields.description: A free-form identifier (a simple number, an alphanumeric code, a URL, etc.) for the resource that is unique and meaningful primarily for the data provider.
fields.comments: Ideally, this would be a globally unique identifier (GUID), but the provider is encouraged to supply any form of identifier that simplifies communications on resources within their project and helps to locate individual data items in the provider's data repositories. It is the provider's decision whether to expose this value or not.
fields.rdfs:comment: A free-form identifier (a simple number, an alphanumeric code, a URL, etc.) for the resource that is unique and meaningful primarily for the data provider.

fields.name: available
fields.title: Available
fields.description: Date (often a range) that the resource became or will become available.
fields.comments: The date (often a range) that the resource became or will become available. The date and time MUST comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004, https://www.iso.org/standard/40874.html. AC datetime values MAY also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus ("forward slash", '/'). A use case is the harvesting of metadata published before the media are available, which are pending a formal publication elsewhere. One important example is the case of metadata that documents an occurrence, which metadata harvesters might exploit without use of the media. See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, for further explanation and examples.
fields.rdfs:comment: Date (often a range) that the resource became or will become available.

fields.name: hasServiceAccessPoint
fields.title: Service Access Point
fields.description: In a chosen serialization (RDF, XML Schema, etc.) the potentially multiple service access points (e.g., for different resolutions of an image) might be provided in a referenced or in a nested object.
fields.comments: This property identifies one such access point. That is, each of potentially multiple values of hasServiceAccessPoint identifies a set of representation-dependent metadata using the properties defined under the Service Access Point Vocabulary section of the Audiovisual Core Term List document. Some serializations may flatten the model of service-access points by (a) dropping ac:hasServiceAccessPoint, ac:variant and ac:variantLiteral, (b) repeating properties from the Service Access Point Vocabulary and prefixing them with values of ac:variantLiteral. If such a flat serialization is necessary for services, we recommend to select from among term names of the form "AB" where "A" is one of thumbnail, trailer, lowerQuality, mediumQuality, goodQuality, bestQuality, offline and "B" is one of AccessURI, Format, Extent, FurtherInformationURL, LicensingException, ServiceExpectation (example: thumbnailAccessURI). Implementers in specific constraint languages such as XML Schema or RDF may wish to make Access URI and perhaps dcterms:format mandatory on instances of the service access point.
fields.rdfs:comment: In a chosen serialization (RDF, XML Schema, etc.) the potentially multiple service access points (e.g., for different resolutions of an image) might be provided in a referenced or in a nested object. This property identifies one such access point. That is, each of potentially multiple values of hasServiceAccessPoint identifies a set of representation-dependent metadata using the properties defined under the Service Access Point Vocabulary section of the Audiovisual Core Term List document.

fields.name: serviceExpectation
fields.title: Service Expectation
fields.description: A term that describes what service expectations users may have of the ac:accessURI.
fields.comments: Recommended terms include online (denotes that the URL is expected to deliver the resource), authenticate (denotes that the URL delivers a login or other authentication interface requiring completion before delivery of the resource) published (non digital, denotes that the URL is the identifier of a non-digital published work, for example a doi.) Communities should develop their own controlled vocabularies for ac:serviceExpectation.
fields.rdfs:comment: A term that describes what service expectations users may have of the ac:accessURI.

fields.name: accessURI
fields.title: Access URI
fields.description: A URI that uniquely identifies a service that provides a representation of the underlying resource.
fields.comments: If this resource can be acquired by an http request, its http URL SHOULD be given. If not, but it has some URI in another URI scheme, that MAY be given here. Value might point to something offline, such as a published CD, etc. For example, the doi of a published CD would be a suitable value.
fields.rdfs:comment: A URI that uniquely identifies a service that provides a representation of the underlying resource.

fields.name: format
fields.title: Format
fields.description: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource, denoted by a controlled value string.
fields.comments: A controlled value string describing the technical format of the resource (file format or physical medium). The string SHOULD be a controlled value from the Audiovisual Core Controlled Vocabulary for Dublin Core dcterms:format, although it MAY be any Media Type (MIME type) value from the IANA list of Media Types (https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) or any commonly used file extension string. Human-readable information about the Controlled Vocabulary for format is at http://rs.tdwg.org/ac/doc/format/. This term can be used to describe offline digital content. In cases where the provided Service Access Point URL includes a standard file extension from which the format can be inferred, it is permissible to not provide a value for this property. See also the entry for dcterms:format in the Audiovisual Core term list document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. It is best practice to use dcterms:format instead of dc:format whenever practical. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.

fields.name: formatIRI
fields.title: Format IRI
fields.description: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource, denoted by an IRI.
fields.comments: An IRI denoting the technical format of the resource (file format or physical medium). The IRI SHOULD be from the Audiovisual Core Controlled Vocabulary for Dublin Core dcterms:format. Human-readable information about the Controlled Vocabulary for dcterms:format is at http://rs.tdwg.org/ac/doc/format/. In cases where an IRI for the format does not exist in the controlled vocabulary, a provider can omit this property and provide a media type or file extension value for dc:format. See the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces, https://web.archive.org/web/20171126043657/https://github.com/dcmi/repository/blob/master/mediawiki_wiki/FAQ/DC_and_DCTERMS_Namespaces.md, for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.

fields.name: variantLiteral
fields.title: Variant Literal
fields.description: The category describing this Service Access Point variant, denoted by a controlled value string.
fields.comments: Values SHOULD be selected from the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:variant. Human-readable information about the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:variant is at http://rs.tdwg.org/ac/doc/variant/. It is best practice to use ac:variant instead of ac:variantLiteral whenever practical.
fields.rdfs:comment: The category describing this Service Access Point variant, denoted by a controlled value string.

fields.name: variantIRI
fields.title: Variant IRI
fields.description: The category describing this Service Access Point variant, denoted by an IRI.
fields.comments: Values SHOULD be selected from the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:variant. Human-readable information about the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:variant is at http://rs.tdwg.org/ac/doc/variant/. In text-based systems such as tables, IRI values MUST be in unabbreviated form.
fields.rdfs:comment: The category describing this Service Access Point variant, denoted by an IRI.

fields.name: variantDescription
fields.title: Variant Description
fields.description: Text that describes this Service Access Point variant.
fields.comments: Most variants (thumb, low-res, high-res) are self-explanatory and it is best practice to leave this property empty if no special description is needed. It is provided for cases that require additional information (e.g., video shortened instead of simply quality reduced).
fields.rdfs:comment: Text that describes this Service Access Point variant

fields.name: PixelXDimension
fields.title: Image Width
fields.description: Information specific to compressed data. When a compressed file is recorded, the valid width of the meaningful image shall be recorded in this tag, whether or not there is padding data or a restart marker.
fields.comments: The width in pixels of the media specified by the access point. Contrary to the definition, in Audiovisual Core, this term MAY be used with uncompressed files. Audiovisual Core uses this term for any image type, including those to which EXIF does not apply and those that are not a compressed file type like JPEG.
fields.rdfs:comment: Information specific to compressed data. When a compressed file is recorded, the valid width of the meaningful image shall be recorded in this tag, whether or not there is padding data or a restart marker. This tag shall not exist in an uncompressed file.

fields.name: PixelYDimension
fields.title: Image Height
fields.description: Information specific to compressed data. When a compressed file is recorded, the valid height of the meaningful image shall be recorded in this tag, whether or not there is padding data or a restart marker.
fields.comments: The height in pixels of the media specified by the access point. Contrary to the definition, in Audiovisual Core, this term MAY be used with uncompressed files. Audiovisual Core uses this term for any image type, including those to which EXIF does not apply and those that are not a compressed file type like JPEG.
fields.rdfs:comment: Information specific to compressed data. When a compressed file is recorded, the valid height of the meaningful image shall be recorded in this tag, whether or not there is padding data or a restart marker. This tag shall not exist in an uncompressed file.

fields.name: hashFunction
fields.title: Hash Function
fields.description: The cryptographic hash function used to compute the value given in the ac:hashValue.
fields.comments: Recommended values include MD5, SHA-1, SHA-224,SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512, SHA-512/224 and SHA-512/256
fields.rdfs:comment: The cryptographic hash function used to compute the value given in the Hash Value.

fields.name: hashValue
fields.title: Hash Value
fields.description: The value computed by an ac:hashFunction applied to the media that will be delivered at the access point.
fields.comments: Best practice is to also specify the ac:hash Function using one of the standard literals from the Notes there.
fields.rdfs:comment: The value computed by a hash function applied to the media that will be delivered at the access point.

fields.name: furtherInformationURL
fields.title: Further Information URL
fields.description: The URL of a Web site that provides additional information about the version of the dwc:Media resource that is provided by the ac:hasServiceAccessPoint.
fields.rdfs:comment: The URL of a Web site that provides additional information about the version of the media resource that is provided by the Service Access Point.

fields.name: commenterLiteral
fields.title: Commenter Literal
fields.description: A name of a dcterms:Agent primarily responsible for providing the ac:comments
fields.comments: See also ac:reviewerComments for the distinction between ac:comments and ac:reviewerComments. See also the entry for ac:commenter and the section Namespaces, Prefixes and Term Names in the Audiovisual Core Term List document for discussion of the rationale for separate terms taking URI values from those taking Literal values where both are possible. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: The name of a person who created a comment, or the literal "anonymous" (= anonymously commented).

fields.name: commenterID
fields.title: Commenter ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dcterms:Agent primarily responsible for providing the ac:comments.
fields.comments: Implementers and communities of practice MAY produce restrictions or recommendations on the choice of vocabularies. See also ac:reviewerComments for the distinction between ac:comments and ac:reviewerComments. See also the entry for ac:commenterLiteral and the section Namespaces, Prefixes and Term Names in the Audiovisual Core Term List document for discussion of the rationale for separate terms taking URI values from those taking Literal values where both are possible. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: A URI denoting a person who created a comment.

fields.name: comments
fields.title: Comments
fields.description: Any comment provided on the dwc:Media resource, as free-form text.
fields.comments: Best practice would also identify the ac:commenter. Comments may refer to the resource itself (e. g., asserting a taxon name or location of a biological subject in an image), or to the relation between resource and associated metadata (e. g., asserting that the taxon name given in the metadata is wrong, without asserting a positive identification). There is a separate item from ac:reviewerComments, which is defined more as an expert-level review. Implementers or communities of practice might establish conventions about the meaning of the absence of an ac:commenter, but this specification is silent on that matter.
fields.rdfs:comment: Any comment provided on the media resource, as free-form text.

fields.name: Rating
fields.title: Rating
fields.description: A user-assigned rating for this file. The value shall be -1 or in the range [0..5], where -1 indicates "rejected" and 0 indicates "unrated". If xmp:Rating is not present, a value of 0 should be assumed.
fields.comments: A rating for a dwc:Media resource, provided by record originators or editors, with '1' (worst) to '5' (best). Anticipated usage is for a typical 'star rating' UI, with the addition of a notion of rejection. Values MAY be decimal numbers in the permitted range. The origin of the rating is not communicated. It may, e. g., be based on user feedback or on editorial ratings. By "user-assigned" is meant assigned by the originator or editor of the record using the term.
fields.rdfs:comment: A user-assigned rating for this file. The value shall be -1 or in the range [0..5], where -1 indicates "rejected" and 0 indicates "unrated". If xmp:Rating is not present, a value of 0 should be assumed.

fields.name: reviewerLiteral
fields.title: Reviewer Literal
fields.description: A name of a dcterms:Agent primarily responsible for providing the ac:reviewerComments
fields.comments: If present, then resource is peer-reviewed, even if ac:reviewerComments is absent or empty. Its presence tells whether an expert in the subject featured in the media has reviewed a dwc:Media resource or collection and approved its metadata description; MUST display a name or the literal "anonymous" (= anonymously reviewed). Provider is asserting they accept this review as competent. See also ac:reviewer and the section Namespaces, Prefixes and Term Names in the Audiovisual Core Term List document for discussion of the rationale for separate terms taking URI values from those taking Literal values where both are possible. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: String providing the name of a reviewer.

fields.name: reviewerID
fields.title: Reviewer ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dcterms:Agent primarily responsible for providing the ac:reviewerComments
fields.comments: If present, then resource is peer-reviewed, even if ac:reviewerComments is absent or empty. Its presence tells whether an expert in the subject featured in the media has reviewed a dwc:Media resource or collection and approved its metadata description; MUST display a name or the literal "anonymous" (= anonymously reviewed). Provider is asserting they accept this review as competent. See also ac:reviewerLiteral and the section Namespaces, Prefixes and Term Names in the Audiovisual Core Term List document for discussion of the rationale for separate terms taking URI values from those taking Literal values where both are possible. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.rdfs:comment: URI for a reviewer.

fields.name: reviewerComments
fields.title: Reviewer Comments
fields.description: Any comment provided by a reviewer with expertise in the subject, as free-form text.
fields.comments: Reviewer Comments may refer to the resource itself (e. g., asserting a taxon name or location of a biological subject in an image), or to the relation between resource and associated metadata (e. g., asserting that the taxon name given in the metadata is wrong, without asserting a positive identification). There is a separate item "Comments" for text from commenters of unrecorded expertise.
fields.rdfs:comment: Any comment provided by a reviewer with expertise in the subject, as free-form text.

fields.name: physicalSetting
fields.title: Physical Setting
fields.description: The setting of the content represented in a dwc:Media resource, such as images, sounds, and movies if the provider deems them relevant.
fields.rdfs:comment: The setting of the content represented in a dwc:Media resource, such as images, sounds, and movies if the provider deems them relevant. Constrained vocabulary of: `Natural` = Object in its natural setting of the object (e. g. living organisms in their natural environment); `Artificial` = Object in an artificial environment (e. g. living organisms in an artificial environment such as a zoo, garden, greenhouse, or laboratory); `Edited` = Human media editing of a natural setting or media acquisition with a separate media background such as a photographic backdrop.

fields.name: subjectCategory
fields.title: Subject Category
fields.description: A category for the content of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: subjectCategoryIRI
fields.title: Subject Category IRI
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: subjectCategorySource
fields.title: Subject Category Source
fields.description: A reference to a controlled vocabulary in which the definition of a value in dwc:subjectCategory is given.
fields.comments: The Audiovisual Core recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.
fields.rdfs:comment: Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.

fields.name: tag
fields.title: Tag
fields.description: General keywords or tags.
fields.comments: Tags may be multi-worded phrases. Where scientific names, common names, geographic locations, etc. are separable, those should go into the more specific coverage metadata items provided further below. Examples: "flower diagram". Character or part keywords like "leaf", or "flower color" are especially desirable.
fields.rdfs:comment: General keywords or tags.

fields.name: subjectPartLiteral
fields.title: Subject Part Literal
fields.description: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the dwc:Media resource, denoted by a controlled value string.
fields.comments: Values SHOULD be selected from the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:subjectPart. It is best practice to use ac:subjectPart instead of ac:subjectPartLiteral whenever practical.
fields.rdfs:comment: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the media resource, denoted by a controlled value string.

fields.name: subjectPartIRI
fields.title: Subject Part IRI
fields.description: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the dwc:Media resource, denoted by an IRI.
fields.rdfs:comment: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the media resource, denoted by an IRI.

fields.name: subjectOrientationLiteral
fields.title: Subject Orientation Literal
fields.description: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the dwc:Media resource with respect to the acquisition device, denoted by a controlled value string.
fields.comments: Values SHOULD be selected from the Controlled Vocabulary for ac:subjectOrientation. It is best practice to use ac:subjectOrientation instead of ac:subjectOrientationLiteral whenever practical.
fields.rdfs:comment: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the media resource with respect to the acquisition device, denoted by a controlled value string.

fields.name: subjectOrientationIRI
fields.title: Subject Orientation IRI
fields.description: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the dwc:Media resource with respect to the acquisition device, denoted by an IRI.
fields.rdfs:comment: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the media resource with respect to the acquisition device, denoted by a controlled value string.

fields.name: startTime
fields.title: Start Time in Seconds
fields.description: The beginning of a temporal region, specified as an absolute offset relative to the beginning of a dwc:Media resource (this corresponds to Normal Play Time RFC 2326), specified as seconds, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer.
fields.comments: This term MUST only be applied to a region of interest.
fields.rdfs:comment: The beginning of a temporal region, specified as an absolute offset relative to the beginning of the media item (this corresponds to Normal Play Time RFC 2326), specified as seconds, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer.

fields.name: endTime
fields.title: End Time in Seconds
fields.description: The end of a temporal region, specified as an absolute offset relative to the beginning of a dwc:Media resource (this corresponds to Normal Play Time RFC 2326), specified as seconds, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer.
fields.comments: This term MUST only be applied to a region of interest.
fields.rdfs:comment: The end of a temporal region, specified as an absolute offset relative to the beginning of the media item (this corresponds to Normal Play Time RFC 2326), specified as seconds, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer.

fields.name: startTimestamp
fields.title: Start Time Stamp
fields.description: The beginning of a temporal region, specified as real-world clock time ISO 8601 timestamps, using UTC timezone, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer. There is no limit on the number of decimal places for the decimal fraction.
fields.comments: This term MAY be applied to a region of interest or an entire media item.
fields.rdfs:comment: The beginning of a temporal region, specified as real-world clock time ISO 8601 timestamps, using UTC timezone, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer. There is no limit on the number of decimal places for the decimal fraction.

fields.name: endTimestamp
fields.title: End Time Stamp
fields.description: The end of a temporal region, specified as real-world clock time ISO 8601 timestamps, using UTC timezone, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer. There is no limit on the number of decimal places for the decimal fraction.
fields.comments: This term MAY be applied to a region of interest or an entire media item.
fields.rdfs:comment: The end of a temporal region, specified as real-world clock time ISO 8601 timestamps, using UTC timezone, with an optional fractional part to indicate milliseconds or finer. There is no limit on the number of decimal places for the decimal fraction.

fields.name: mediaDuration
fields.title: Media Duration
fields.description: The playback duration of an audio or video file in seconds.
fields.comments: This might be different from the time in seconds calculated as the difference of ac:endTimestamp and ac:startTimestamp if ac:mediaSpeed is not equal to 1.
fields.rdfs:comment: The playback duration of an audio or video file in seconds.

fields.name: mediaSpeed
fields.title: Media Speed
fields.description: The decimal fraction representing the natural speed over the encoded speed.
fields.comments: If a value for ac:mediaSpeed is not provided, applications SHOULD assume that 1.0 is the value. For example, in a time-lapse recording where 60 seconds of natural time is represented in 1 second of media this would be 60. In a time-expanded recording where 1 second of recording is represented in 5 seconds of media, this would be 0.2.
fields.rdfs:comment: The decimal fraction representing the natural speed over the encoded speed.

fields.name: freqHigh
fields.title: Upper frequency bound
fields.description: The highest frequency of the phenomena reflected in the multimedia item or Region of Interest.
fields.comments: Numeric value in hertz (Hz). This term refers to the sound events depicted and not to the constraints of the recording medium, so are in principle independent from sampleRate. If dwc:scientificName is specified and if applied to the entire multimedia item, these frequency bounds refer to the sounds of the species given in the dwc:scientificName throughout the whole recording. Although many users will specify both freqLow and freqHigh, it is permitted to specify just one or the other, for example if only one of the bounds is discernible.
fields.rdfs:comment: The highest frequency of the phenomena reflected in the multimedia item or Region of Interest.

fields.name: freqLow
fields.title: Lower frequency bound
fields.description: The lowest frequency of the phenomena reflected in the multimedia item or Region of Interest.
fields.comments: Numeric value in hertz (Hz). This term refers to the sound events depicted and not to the constraints of the recording medium, so are in principle independent from sampleRate. If dwc:scientificName is specified and if applied to the entire multimedia item, these frequency bounds refer to the sounds of the species given in the dwc:scientificName throughout the whole recording. Although many users will specify both freqLow and freqHigh, it is permitted to specify just one or the other, for example if only one of the bounds is discernible.
fields.rdfs:comment: The lowest frequency of the phenomena reflected in the multimedia item or Region of Interest.

fields.name: xFrac
fields.title: Fractional X
fields.description: The horizontal position of a reference point, measured from the left side of a dwc:Media resource and expressed as a decimal fraction of the width of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: A valid value MUST be greater than or equal to zero and less than or equal to one. The precision of this value SHOULD be great enough that when the ac:xFrac value is multiplied by the exif:PixelXDimension of the Best Quality variant of the Service Access point, rounding to the nearest integer results in the same horizontal pixel location originally used to define the point. This point can serve as the horizontal position of the upper left corner of a bounding rectangle, or as the center of a circle.
fields.rdfs:comment: The horizontal position of a reference point, measured from the left side of the media item and expressed as a decimal fraction of the width of the media item.

fields.name: yFrac
fields.title: Fractional Y
fields.description: The vertical position of a reference point, measured from the top of a dwc:Media resource and expressed as a decimal fraction of the height of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: A valid value MUST be greater than or equal to zero and less than or equal to one. The precision of this value SHOULD be great enough that when the ac:yFrac value is multiplied by the exif:PixelYDimension of the Best Quality variant of the Service Access point, rounding to the nearest integer results in the same vertical pixel originally used to define the point. This point can serve as the vertical position of the upper left corner of a bounding rectangle, or as the center of a circle.
fields.rdfs:comment: The vertical position of a reference point, measured from the top of the media item and expressed as a decimal fraction of the height of the media item.

fields.name: heightFrac
fields.title: Fractional Height
fields.description: The height of the bounding rectangle, expressed as a decimal fraction of the height of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: The sum of a valid value plus ac:yFrac MUST be greater than zero and less than or equal to one. The precision of this value SHOULD be great enough that when ac:heightFrac and ac:yFrac are used with the exif:PixelYDimension of the Best Quality variant of the Service Access point to calculate the lower right corner of the rectangle, rounding to the nearest integer results in the same vertical pixel originally used to define the point. This term MUST NOT be used with ac:radius to define a region of interest. Zero-sized bounding rectangles are not allowed. To designate a point, use the radius option with a zero value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The height of the bounding rectangle, expressed as a decimal fraction of the height of the media item.

fields.name: widthFrac
fields.title: Fractional Width
fields.description: The width of the bounding rectangle, expressed as a decimal fraction of the width of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: The sum of a valid value plus ac:xFrac MUST be greater than zero and less than or equal to one. The precision of this value SHOULD be great enough that when ac:widthFrac and ac:xFrac are used with the exif:PixelXDimension of the Best Quality variant of the Service Access point to calculate the lower right corner of the rectangle, rounding to the nearest integer results in the same horizontal pixel originally used to define the point. This term MUST NOT be used with ac:radius to define a region of interest. Zero-sized bounding rectangles are not allowed. To designate a point, use the radius option with a zero value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The width of the bounding rectangle, expressed as a decimal fraction of the width of the media item.

fields.name: radius
fields.title: Radius
fields.description: The radius of a bounding circle or arc, expressed as a fraction of the width of a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: A valid value MUST be greater than or equal to zero. A valid value MAY cause the designated circle to extend beyond the bounds of a dwc:Media resource. In that case, the arc within a dwc:Media resource plus the bounds of a dwc:Media resource specify the region of interest. This term MUST NOT be used with ac:widthFrac or ac:heightFrac to define a region of interest. This term may be used with ac:xFrac and ac:yFrac to define a point. In that case, the implication is that the point falls on some object of interest within a dwc:Media resource, but nothing more can be assumed about the bounds of that object.
fields.rdfs:comment: The radius of a bounding circle or arc, expressed as a fraction of the width of the media item.

fields.name: provenanceID
fields.title: Provenance ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Provenance.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: usagePolicyID
fields.title: Usage Policy ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:UsagePolicy.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.title: Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the dwc:Occurrence (as opposed to a particular digital record of the dwc:Occurrence). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.

fields.name: eventID
fields.title: Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the set of information associated with a dwc:Event (something that occurs at a place and time). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.

fields.name: recordedBy
fields.title: Recorded By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of dcterms:Agents responsible for recording a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `). This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.examples: `Jos√© E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson` (where the value in dwc:collectorNumber `OPP 7101` corresponds to the collector number for the specimen in the field catalog of Oliver P. Pearson)
fields.rdfs:comment: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations responsible for recording the original dwc:Occurrence. The primary collector or observer, especially one who applies a personal identifier (dwc:recordNumber), should be listed first.

fields.name: recordedByID
fields.title: Recorded By ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dcterms:Agent responsible for recording a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.rdfs:comment: A list (concatenated and separated) of the globally unique identifier for the person, people, groups, or organizations responsible for recording the original dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: organismQuantity
fields.title: Organism Quantity
fields.description: A number or enumeration value for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.
fields.comments: A dwc:organismQuantity must have a corresponding dwc:organismQuantityType.
fields.examples: `27` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType); `12.5` (organismQuantity) with `% biomass` (organismQuantityType); `r` (organismQuantity) with `Braun-Blanquet Scale` (organismQuantityType); `many` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType)
fields.rdfs:comment: A number or enumeration value for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.

fields.name: organismQuantityType
fields.title: Organism Quantity Type
fields.description: The type of quantification system used for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.
fields.comments: A dwc:organismQuantityType must have a corresponding dwc:organismQuantity. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.examples: `27` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType); `12.5` (organismQuantity) with `% biomass` (organismQuantityType); `r` (organismQuantity) with `Braun-Blanquet Scale` (organismQuantityType); `many` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType)
fields.rdfs:comment: The type of quantification system used for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.

fields.name: sex
fields.title: Sex
fields.description: A sex of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The sex of the biological individual(s) represented in the dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: lifeStage
fields.title: Life Stage
fields.description: An age class or life stage of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The age class or life stage of the dwc:Organism(s) at the time the dwc:Occurrence was recorded.

fields.name: reproductiveCondition
fields.title: Reproductive Condition
fields.description: A reproductive condition of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The reproductive condition of the biological individual(s) represented in the dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: caste
fields.title: Caste
fields.description: A social caste of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary that aligns best with a dwc:Taxon. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: Categorisation of individuals for eusocial species (including some mammals and arthropods).

fields.name: behavior
fields.title: Behavior
fields.description: A behavior shown by a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The behavior shown by the subject at the time the dwc:Occurrence was recorded.

fields.name: vitality
fields.title: Vitality
fields.description: An indication of whether a dwc:Organism was alive or dead at the time of collection or observation.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: An indication of whether a dwc:Organism was alive or dead at the time of collection or observation.

fields.name: establishmentMeans
fields.title: Establishment Means
fields.description: Statement about whether a dwc:Organism has been introduced to a given place and time through the direct or indirect activity of modern humans.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/em/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: Statement about whether a dwc:Organism has been introduced to a given place and time through the direct or indirect activity of modern humans.

fields.name: degreeOfEstablishment
fields.title: Degree Of Establishment
fields.description: The degree to which a dwc:Organism survives, reproduces, and expands its range at the given place and time.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/doe/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The degree to which a dwc:Organism survives, reproduces, and expands its range at the given place and time.

fields.name: pathway
fields.title: Pathway
fields.description: The process by which a dwc:Organism came to be in a given place at a given time.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/pw/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: The process by which a dwc:Organism came to be in a given place at a given time.

fields.name: substrate
fields.title: Substrate
fields.description: A biotic or abiotic material to which an dwc:Organism is attached when a dwc:Event occurs.
fields.comments: This may or may not imply that the organism influenced/took resources from the substrate (such as during parasitization or decomposition). Declaration of a host-parasite relationship is better expressed as an organism interaction.

fields.name: occurrenceStatus
fields.title: Occurrence Status
fields.description: A statement about the detection or non-detection of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: For dwc:Occurrences, the default vocabulary is recommended to consist of 'detected' and 'notDetected', but can be extended by implementers with good justification. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.rdfs:comment: A statement about the presence or absence of a dwc:Taxon at a dcterms:Location.

fields.name: occurrenceReferences
fields.title: Occurrence References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of dcterms:BibliographicResources associated with a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`
fields.rdfs:comment: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with the dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: informationWithheld
fields.title: Information Withheld
fields.description: Additional information that exists about a resource, but that is not shared publicly.
fields.examples: `location information not given for endangered species`; `collector identities withheld | ask about tissue samples`
fields.rdfs:comment: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.

fields.name: dataGeneralizations
fields.title: Data Generalizations
fields.description: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
fields.examples: `Coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell.`
fields.rdfs:comment: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.

fields.name: occurrenceRemarks
fields.title: Occurrence Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about the dwc:Occurrence.
fields.rdfs:comment: Comments or notes about the dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: organismScope
fields.title: Organism Scope
fields.description: A description of the type of a dwc:Organism instance.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. Can be used to indicate whether a dwc:Organism instance represents a discrete organism or if it represents a particular type of aggregation.
fields.rdfs:comment: A description of the kind of dwc:Organism instance. Can be used to indicate whether the dwc:Organism instance represents a discrete organism or if it represents a particular type of aggregation.

fields.name: organismName
fields.title: Organism Name
fields.description: A name or label assigned to a dwc:Organism.
fields.rdfs:comment: A textual name or label assigned to a dwc:Organism instance.

fields.name: causeOfDeath
fields.title: Cause Of Death
fields.description: An indication of the known or suspected cause of death of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: The cause may be due to natural causes (e.g., disease, predation), human-related activities (e.g., roadkill, pollution), or other environmental factors (e.g., extreme weather events).
fields.rdfs:comment: An indication of the known or suspected cause of death of a dwc:Organism.

fields.name: organismRemarks
fields.title: Organism Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: `One of a litter of six`
fields.rdfs:comment: Comments or notes about the dwc:Organism instance.

fields.name: verbatimIdentification
fields.title: Verbatim Identification
fields.description: A string representing a taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record.
fields.examples: `Peromyscus sp.`; `Ministrymon sp. nov. 1`; `Anser anser √ó Branta canadensis`; `Pachyporidae?`, `Potentilla √ó pantotricha Soj√°k`; `Aconitum pilipes √ó A. variegatum; `Lepomis auritus x cyanellus`
fields.rdfs:comment: A string representing the taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record.

fields.name: identifiedBy
fields.title: Identified By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of dcterms:Agents responsible for making a taxonomic determination of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: When used in the context of a Survey, the subject consists of all of the dwc:Identifications related to the Event. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.rdfs:comment: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who assigned the dwc:Taxon to the subject.

fields.name: dateIdentified
fields.title: Date Identified
fields.description: A date on which the subject was determined as representing a dwc:Taxon.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
fields.examples: `1963-03-08T14:07-06:00` (8 Mar 1963 at or after 2:07pm and before 2:08pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 at or after 8:40am and before 8:41 UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (29 August 2018 at or after 3:19pm and before 3:20pm local time); `1809-02-12` (within the day 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (in the month of June 1906); `1971` (in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time within the interval beginning 1 March 2007 at 1pm UTC and before 11 May 2008 at 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time within the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and before the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between the beginning of 13 November 2007 and before 15 November 2007)
fields.rdfs:comment: The date on which the subject was determined as representing the dwc:Taxon.

fields.name: identificationReferences
fields.title: Identification References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of dcterms:BibliographicResources used in a dwc:Identification.
fields.comments: When used in the context of a Survey, the subject consists of all of the dwc:Identifications related to the Survey. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `Aves del Noroeste Patagonico. Christie et al. 2004.`; `Stebbins, R. Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. 3rd Edition. 2003. | Irschick, D.J. and Shaffer, H.B. (1997). The polytypic species revisited: Morphological differentiation among tiger salamanders (Ambystoma tigrinum) (Amphibia: Caudata). Herpetologica, 53(1), 30-49.`
fields.rdfs:comment: A list (concatenated and separated) of references (publication, global unique identifier, URI) used in the dwc:Identification.

fields.name: identificationVerificationStatus
fields.title: Identification Verification Status
fields.description: A categorical indicator of the extent to which a taxonomic determination has been verified to be correct.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as that used in HISPID and ABCD.
fields.rdfs:comment: A categorical indicator of the extent to which the taxonomic identification has been verified to be correct.

fields.name: identificationRemarks
fields.title: Identification Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Identification.
fields.examples: `Distinguished between Anthus correndera and Anthus hellmayri based on the comparative lengths of the u√±as.`
fields.rdfs:comment: Comments or notes about the dwc:Identification.

fields.name: taxonID
fields.title: Taxon ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Taxon.
fields.comments: In DwC-DP, the taxonID is always an external link to a taxon record. As such, if present, it should be a resolvable globally unique identifier. See the Identifiers section of https://github.com/CatalogueOfLife/coldp/blob/master/README.md.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the set of dwc:Taxon information. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.

fields.name: scientificNameID
fields.title: Scientific Name ID
fields.description: An identifier for the nomenclatural (not taxonomic) details of a scientific name.
fields.comments: In DwC-DP, the taxonID is always an external link to a taxon record. As such, if present, it should be a resolvable globally unique identifier. See the Identifiers section of https://github.com/CatalogueOfLife/coldp/blob/master/README.md.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the nomenclatural (not taxonomic) details of a scientific name.

fields.name: scientificName
fields.title: Scientific Name
fields.description: A scientific name string, not including authorship, date or identification qualifiers.
fields.examples: `Coleoptera` (order); `Vespertilionidae` (family); `Manis` (genus); `Ctenomys sociabilis` (genus + specificEpithet); `Ambystoma tigrinum diaboli` (genus + specificEpithet + infraspecificEpithet); `Quercus agrifolia var. oxyadenia` (genus + specificEpithet + taxonRank + infraspecificEpithet); `√óAgropogon littoralis`; `Mentha √ósmithiana`; `Agrostis stolonifera L. √ó Polypogon monspeliensis`
fields.rdfs:comment: The full scientific name, with authorship and date information if known. When forming part of a dwc:Identification, this should be the name in lowest level taxonomic rank that can be determined. This term should not contain identification qualifications, which should instead be supplied in the dwc:identificationQualifier term.

fields.name: scientificNameAuthorship
fields.title: Scientific Name Authorship
fields.description: The authorship information for a dwc:scientificName formatted according to the conventions of the applicable dwc:nomenclaturalCode.
fields.rdfs:comment: The authorship information for the dwc:scientificName formatted according to the conventions of the applicable dwc:nomenclaturalCode.

fields.name: vernacularName
fields.title: Vernacular Name
fields.description: A common or vernacular name.
fields.rdfs:comment: A common or vernacular name.

fields.name: taxonRank
fields.title: Taxon Rank
fields.description: A taxonomic rank of the most specific name in a dwc:scientificName.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. The taxon ranks of algae, fungi and plants are defined in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (Schenzhen Code Articles H3.2, H4.4 and H.3.1).
fields.rdfs:comment: The taxonomic rank of the most specific name in the dwc:scientificName.

fields.name: externalClassificationSource
fields.title: External Classification Source
fields.description: A reference to a source outside the dataset where the identifying name, code, or taxon concept can be found.
fields.comments: The external source applies to whichever of dwc:taxonID, dwc:scientificNameID, minext:geoClassificationCode, minext:geoName, dwc:scientificName, or dwc:vernacularName is populated.
fields.examples: `http://www.catalogueoflife.org/data/taxon/`; `https://avibase.bsc-eoc.org/`; `Dana, J. D., Dana, E. S., & Gaines, R. V. (1997). Dana's new mineralogy: The system of mineralogy of James Dwight Dana and Edward Salisbury Dana.`; `Strunz H, Nickel EH (2001) Strunz Mineralogical Tables, 9th Edition. Berlin and Stuttgart 870 pp.`
fields.rdfs:comment: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

fields.name: feedbackURL
fields.title: Feedback URL
fields.description: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to optionally include query strings that act to pre-populate web page form elements and communicate the context.
fields.rdfs:comment: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.

fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.title: Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make a dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the dwc:Occurrence (as opposed to a particular digital record of the dwc:Occurrence). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.

fields.name: assertionID
fields.title: Assertion ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: verbatimAssertionType
fields.title: Verbatim Assertion Type
fields.description: A string representing the type of dwc:Assertion as it appeared in the original record.
fields.comments: This term is meant to allow the capture of an unaltered original name for a dwc:assertionType. This term is meant to be used in addition to dwc:assertionType, not instead of it.

fields.name: assertionType
fields.title: Assertion Type
fields.description: A category that best matches the nature of a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: assertionTypeIRI
fields.title: Assertion Type (IRI)
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for a type of dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionTypeSource
fields.title: Assertion Type Source
fields.description: A reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of a value in dwc:assertionType is given.
fields.rdfs:comment: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

fields.name: assertionMadeDate
fields.title: Assertion Made Date
fields.description: A date on which a dwc:Assertion was created.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
fields.examples: `1963-03-08T14:07-06:00` (8 Mar 1963 at or after 2:07pm and before 2:08pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 at or after 8:40am and before 8:41 UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (29 August 2018 at or after 3:19pm and before 3:20pm local time); `1809-02-12` (within the day 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (in the month of June 1906); `1971` (in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time within the interval beginning 1 March 2007 at 1pm UTC and before 11 May 2008 at 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time within the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and before the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between the beginning of 13 November 2007 and before 15 November 2007)

fields.name: assertionEffectiveDate
fields.title: Assertion Effective Date
fields.description: A date on which a state or measurement of a dwc:Assertion was deemed to first be in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
fields.examples: `1963-03-08T14:07-06:00` (8 Mar 1963 at or after 2:07pm and before 2:08pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 at or after 8:40am and before 8:41 UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (29 August 2018 at or after 3:19pm and before 3:20pm local time); `1809-02-12` (within the day 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (in the month of June 1906); `1971` (in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time within the interval beginning 1 March 2007 at 1pm UTC and before 11 May 2008 at 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time within the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and before the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between the beginning of 13 November 2007 and before 15 November 2007)

fields.name: assertionValue
fields.title: Assertion Value
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is not numeric.

fields.name: assertionValueIRI
fields.title: Assertion Value (IRI)
fields.description: An IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for a value of a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionValueSource
fields.title: Assertion Value Source
fields.description: A reference to a controlled vocabulary in which the definition of a value in dwc:assertionValue is given.
fields.rdfs:comment: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

fields.name: assertionValueNumeric
fields.title: Assertion Value Numeric
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is numeric.

fields.name: assertionUnit
fields.title: Assertion Unit
fields.description: Unit associated with the value in dwc:assertionValue or dwc:assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI. For units that are composed of multiple parts, use the patterns as given in "A Primer for Communicating Mathematics via Plain Text" (https://cse.sc.edu/~fenner/latex-ASCII.pdf) by Stephen Fenner (e.g., `g/cm^3` for grams per cubic centimeter). For other units, provide the value as a recognizable standard (e.g., '%') or written out in full and in the plural (e.g., `individuals`). It is fine to provide non-SI units in the original language of the dataset.

fields.name: assertionUnitIRI
fields.title: Assertion Unit (IRI)
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for the unit of a dwc:assertionValue or a dwc:assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionUnitSource
fields.title: Assertion Unit Source
fields.description: A reference to a controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in dwc:assertionUnit is given.
fields.rdfs:comment: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

fields.name: assertionError
fields.title: Assertion Error
fields.description: The description of the potential error associated with dwc:assertionValueNumeric.

fields.name: assertionBy
fields.title: Assertion By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of dcterms:Agents responsible for making a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

fields.name: assertionByID
fields.title: Assertion By ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dcterms:Agent responsible for making a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: assertionProtocols
fields.title: Assertion Protocols
fields.description: Names of, references to, or descriptions of dwc:Protocols used in making a dwc:Assertion.

fields.name: assertionReferences
fields.title: Assertion References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of dcterms:BibliographicResources associated with a dwc:Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

fields.name: assertionRemarks
fields.title: Assertion Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Assertion.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Media resource.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.title: Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make a dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.
fields.rdfs:comment: An identifier for the dwc:Occurrence (as opposed to a particular digital record of the dwc:Occurrence). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.

fields.name: subjectCategory
fields.title: Subject Category
